column9: https://emilymarkowitz-noaa.github.io/RWorkshopForRACEGAP/sessions.html
Notes
Welcome!

**Agenda**

1. Open R Studio and check it out: 
R project
Keyboard shortcuts (Tools > Keyboard shortcuts)
Workflow (good file structure)- example
2. Basic math
3. Vectors, Matrices, Arrays, Lists, and Data Frames
4. Best Practices Review

Phew, That was a lot!
![](`r https://rforcats.net/assets/img/programmer.png`)

Resources

1. Intro to R for Data Science (Hadley Wickham): https://r4ds.had.co.nz/index.html
2. Advanced R (Hadley Wickham): https://adv-r.hadley.nz/
3. Cheatsheets (in general): https://rstudio.com/resources/cheatsheets/
4. Provide specific ones at each class
5. Base R cheatsheet
6. Intro to R course & slides: http://ericdunford.com/ppol670/ 
7. Our Coding Club: https://ourcodingclub.github.io/tutorials.html 
8. Swirl R Package: https://swirlstats.com/students.html

An informal opprotunity to come by to ask any questions you have about the course, content, or with specific questions about issues you have with the homework or in your own analyses.

Today's Homework
1. Series of tasks in Excel and then in R
Answers will be added here.

Agenda

1. The importance of checking as you go.  ; 
2. Loading libraries (e.g. tidyverse: install.packages() and library())
3. Best practices - ‘renv’ package to track package versions in projects

*Note that after this lessson we will be using Tidy.

Take a breather!

Agenda

1. Learn about how to write and prepare a script by 1. conforming to a predictable script structure, 2. annotation, 3. never repeating code, 4. naming files with predictable and helpful names, 5. predictable folder structure, 6. scripts with specific tasks, 7. saving scripts in an “R Project.
